user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of add_response_entry_n:
```c
static bool
add_response_entry_n (struct MHD_Response *response,
                      enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                      const char *header,
                      size_t header_len,
                      const char *content,
                      size_t content_len)
{
  if (NULL == response)
    return false;
  if (0 == header_len)
    return false;
  if (0 == content_len)
    return false;
  if (NULL != memchr (header, '\t', header_len))
    return false;
  if (NULL != memchr (header, ' ', header_len))
    return false;
  if (NULL != memchr (header, '\r', header_len))
    return false;
  if (NULL != memchr (header, '\n', header_len))
    return false;
  if (NULL != memchr (content, '\r', content_len))
    return false;
  if (NULL != memchr (content, '\n', content_len))
    return false;

  return MHD_add_response_entry_no_check_ (response, kind, header, header_len,
                                           content, content_len);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No compiler-specific language extensions are used in the provided code. The code uses only standard C constructs and standard library functions: a static function definition, the bool type (standard since C99 via <stdbool.h>), enum, struct pointers, size_t, NULL, and calls to the standard library function memchr. There are no occurrences of known compiler extensions such as __attribute__, __asm__, asm, __builtin_*, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }), nested functions, vector extensions, extended integer types, or other vendor-specific keywords or pragmas. The identifier names (e.g. MHD_add_response_entry_no_check_) may reference project-specific APIs but are not language extensions. Therefore there are no fragments that need investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
